modules.title: 1. What is the Big Bang Theory?
modules.content: The Big Bang Theory explains the origin of the universe as starting from a single point and expanding over time.

modules.title: 2. Evidence for the Big Bang
modules.content: Scientists support the Big Bang Theory with evidence such as cosmic microwave background radiation and the redshift of galaxies.

modules.title: 3. Timeline of the Universe
modules.content: This module covers the timeline from the Big Bang to the formation of galaxies, stars, and planets.

modules.title: 1. What is a Limit?
modules.content: A limit is a fundamental concept in calculus that describes the value a function approaches as the input approaches a certain value.

modules.title: 2. Limit Notation
modules.content: The limit of a function f(x) as x approaches a is written as lim xâ†’a f(x).

subtopics.title: Left-Hand Limit
subtopics.content: The limit of a function as it approaches a value from the left side.

subtopics.title: Right-Hand Limit
subtopics.content: The limit of a function as it approaches a value from the right side.

modules.title: 4. Limits at Infinity
modules.content: Limits can also describe the behavior of functions as x approaches infinity or negative infinity.

modules.title: 5. When Limits Do Not Exist
modules.content: A limit does not exist if the left-hand and right-hand limits are not equal, or if the function behaves erratically near the point.

modules.title: 1. What is an Operating System?
modules.content: An operating system (OS) is system software that manages hardware and software resources and provides services for computer programs.

subtopics.title: Batch Operating System
subtopics.content: Processes are batched together and executed without interaction from the user.

subtopics.title: Time-Sharing Operating System
subtopics.content: Allows multiple users to use the system simultaneously by sharing time slices.

subtopics.title: Real-Time Operating System
subtopics.content: Used for systems that require immediate processing and responses, such as embedded systems.

modules.title: 3. Functions of an Operating System
modules.content: Operating systems handle memory management, process scheduling, input/output control, file systems, and security.

modules.title: 4. User Interfaces in OS
modules.content: OS provides command-line interface (CLI) and graphical user interface (GUI) for interaction with the system.

subtopics.title: Windows
subtopics.content: Developed by Microsoft, widely used in personal and business computers.

subtopics.title: Linux
subtopics.content: An open-source OS used in servers, desktops, and embedded systems.

subtopics.title: macOS
subtopics.content: Developed by Apple, known for its smooth interface and tight hardware integration.
